comment: concentration reported in items/km2. Assumed full circle opening of net submerged. Averaged towing times (hr, table 1).

assumed full neuston net mouth submerged during sampling. Took mean counts by item type (table 1), summed and divided by the volume I estimated from net dimensions & tow time+speed. Keep in mind: this is an old study of an old marine.

average tow surface area given, multiplied by 1/2 of trawl opening. Assumed 1/2 of trawl mouth submerged. Converted concentration to /m3 in this way. "each tow sampled approximately 190m2 of sea surface, assuming efficient net operation".
included only surface level trawls (averaged across sites). Volume from mesh opening (1/2 height used) trawl time and trawl speed. Concentrations of surface-only from figure 1.

location: Saint Peter and Saint Paul Archipelago
comment: for volume: assumed full net submerged and averaged deployment time range. Sampled depth: 0-.6m
volume is calculated averaging neuston & manta net dimensions/deployment time (assuming manta 1/2 submerged). No specific separation steps mentioned
report in terms of /m2 but also say sampled top 10cm of water. Divided reported concentration by depth. "strong wind event"

estuarine rivers. Reported in items/km2 but I've divided by reported depth of sampling (0-15cm). Volume is distance trawled (avg'ed)*net width * depth sampled (.15). GPS distance not explicitly specified, only "trawl distance", but I've inferred it here.

reported in items/km2. I've converted to /m2 and then divided by net height/2. assumption I've made for volume & concentration is that 1/2 of manta net mouth is submerged during sampling. They calculated distance traveled by multiplying boat speed with 60min constant trawl time.

took average of "approximately 1.5-2.5 knots" and assumed half of manta net opening was submerged. ?? ** not sure about polymer type and particle type--may have interpreted their words incorrectly about dominant types.
calls it a handnet, but is discrete then filtered
estuary, triplicates, assumed full manta net submerged, they share doubt about their volume measurements (and therefore never calculated concentration). No distance or flow measurements presented.
reported volume range 44.6-83.1m3, evidence my calculation is actually an underestimate. Assumed 1/2 of manta net was submerged
Oddly looks like bulk sample collected with pump or autosampler in supp materials photo. But all description sounds like large dipped jug instead.
3 replicates at each site

estuary. Total count includes bottom haul samples. 3 top and 3 bottom samples were taken at each point. Types of plastics are only for surface (estimated from fig 5) but colors are for surface and bottom combined.
mediterranean sea. Textile fibers and paint fragments omited from count categorically

gulf of finland, "most of the times a tow lasted for 10min at a speed of 2.5 knots" so I've used this to calculate volume. Ignored two pump concentrations because of unclear volume-concentration relationships
east china sea (left out estuary), each sampling has volume given--I've averaged them

total_particles_collected: mentions samples stored in saturated salt solution, but doesn't specifically say how they were separated out from it. I've assumed this counts as a density separation
comment: divided items/km2 by 1/2 of net opening height. Average volume sampled given. Included only lake samples, but could easily include a row for the river samples, as well. Platic types  not separated by location, but included here anyway. No mention of how blanks were treated (or what was found in them)
mongolia. Assumed manta net 1/2 submerged. Divided average concentration (items/km2) by 1/2 manta height
estimated volume based on trawl & given "submerged area of the net mouth (1.00m x 0.25m)"
same study as above. Depth of 1m. Two replicate pump samples passed through sieve

only amsterdam canals included in this row. Says smallest size examined was 10 micron, but no step of the method describes how they enforce that level, so I've chosen to include the filter size in the lowest size box.
sampling depth = 0-0.5
sampling depth = 0-0.5
consider ignoring: blended method (dipped bucket then poured through handnet)--called handnet method in paper. 30cm below surface

total_particles_collected: "Thus, a consensus for a standard sampling protocol is required for local or global comparison of the distribution characteristics and/or the abundances of microplastics in SSW" (above fig 3)
comment: not-quite-surface: mouth of net below water surface
used two different flow meters (not wure if at once or for different sampling events. Fibers excluded
averaged concentration from table 1. used distances in table 1 (avged) and net mouth size to calculate volume sampled (assumed 1/2 net mouth submerged)
concentration given in /km2: I divided by 1/2 net opening. Volume given. Density, enzyme & WPO separation all used.

Maine coast, paired samples. They calculated volume sampled by submerged mouth opening area x tow distance. In paper, concentration reported /km2. I've converted. (I've assumed distance was calculated by GPS, but this is actually unspecified in the paper). Not explicit about whether blanks were subtracted. I've assumed they were not.
Maine coast, paired samples. Not explicit about whether blanks were subtracted. I've assumed they were not.

!!do they underestimate volume sampled?? assumed half of net opening submerged. Averaged distance towed. Reservoir on river. Left out info that reservoir flow was 1km/hr because no info on direction of tow relative to flow. Averaged mainstream with tributary. actually reservoir with flow, not actually lake, but whatever [I have inferred they got distance from GPS but not specified in text]
all lake concentrations averaged. Summed all plastic concentration less than 4.75 to get concentration items/km2. Then divided by 1/2 mouth height
5 replicates at each station. Each estuary mean given in terms of items/10,000L. Says FTIR used for particles hard to ID, but no results given for theses
given: average tow speed, averaged depth sampled (.1-.16). Calculated volume.
volume given by tow in supp material

ignored .05mm sieve values becaues volume sampled varied. Volume given by sample in supp material (averaged .33 pump amounts only). Concentration values in text don't exactly match those in supp materials. I've used those in text.

included only 0.5m depth. Integrated water sampler. Number of total particles likely includes particles found in deeper samples, but otherwise, I have included only concentration values & fiber-fragment prevelance from depth = 0.5 (supp table A1)
avg'ed nov & feb sampling effort avgs. MP concentration available for each station & month. WP2 net is vertical plankton net, but they towed it horizontally.
top .2m of water column. Rainy and dry season samples.

average data also available. They got volume by measuring tow distance and estimating that 70% of net mouth was submerged. Ignored bongo nets, since those were vertical tows. Their methods explanation: "First, net sampling implicitly introduces bias based on the mesh size selected. Second, size spectrum theory for particulate matter in the marine environment predicts an inverse relationship between abundance and particle size (Sheldon and Parsons, 1967)"
"net & grab should be considered complementary, sampling different parts of mp pollution"
mediterranean coast
29 different rivers across 6 states. Full data available here: https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/5748a29be4b07e28b664dd62

average tow length given in supp materials. Additional info in table 1. volume calculated by float method varified by current meter (but no mention that this was done at mouth of net and not just in surrounding waters)

paired. microftir. Particle totals and subset looked at under FTIR is for sediment water, grab and net samples all together. Concentration converted from /km2 using given sampling depth ("less than .3m"). Averaged regional average values from fig 2a. "Background contamination represented 6.8% of the average abundance of microplastic detected in field samples"
Average of all three sampling locations. Only 10% of particles were subjected to WPO, the rest were counted without any separation, so I've said "none" for separation
paired. steel sampler. 3 samples at each site, pooled into 5L total. "Background contamination represented 6.8% of the average abundance of microplastic detected in field samples"
manta net (ignored bongo net in study). Sampled "top 15cm". Plymoth bay only (could go back and incorporate portaferry values too but they use two different mesh sizes
niskin, 10+ meters below the surface :(

two replicates at each sample, averaged all 20 lakes sampled (individual lake values available in Supp Mat). Types of polymer not listed by site in study, so I haven't included them in these rows. study-average (44 FTIR'ed particles) for all three entries were #1: PET, #2 most common: PP

two replicates at each sample, yangtze river. Types of polymer not listed by site in study, so I haven't included them in these rows. study-average (44 FTIR'ed particles) for all three entries were #1: PET, #2 most common: PP

two replicates at each sample, hanjiang river. Types of polymer not listed by site in study, so I haven't included them in these rows. study-average (44 FTIR'ed particles) for all three entries were #1: PET, #2 most common: PP
paired. Nearshore. Concentrations are medians

re: separation-- says they sent off samples to isolate plastic fragments but doesn't list any specifics about how that was done before immediately talking about visual id, so I'm guessing that's how it was separated (and have written "none" in the separation column)
yellow sea. "only a few syntheic fibers were detected in the blank samples" is as specific as the methods get (paragraph 1, section 3.1)
assumed half of manta opening was submerged. Included only "microplastics" not "all plastic samples" for concentration value here
used hot needle test and then Raman
paired. Middle of the river. Concentrations are medians

I've calculated volume based on averaging tow distance range (530m-3780m) and multiplying it by net width * 1/2 net height (assuming half submerged). Averaged all 3 years, all sites concentration (items/km2), then divided by half of net height
Qinghai lake. Included lake samples only (no river). Assumed half of trawl mouth was submerged.

gulf of lion (med sea). Omited river sample. Averaged all other sample site average concentrations. Assumed 1/2 of net submerged. Ignored the fact that two samples were taken with smaller mesh size (0.33). No GPS specifically mentioned, but I've assumed. Includes triplicate trawls on single sample date: vary 9-fold in concentration
used water surface only. Average volume & concentration calculated from: https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/5cb0d7bfe4b0c3b0065741b0
surface sampling 0-16cm
average tow distance given. No secondary microscopy performed
distance*net opening = volume. GPS coordinate in this row is a guess.
sampled at .3m water depth. Niskin hydrophore. Microftir
citsci, 1L target volume not always met (open marine always higher than coastal samples)
citsci gallatin. Lowest size counted were 0.1mm, but actual size enforcementby filter 0.00045. no mention of using values from blanks to correct measurements
Indonesia

given concentration range and I've estimated the additional values from the graph. No details provided about "blank experiments [that] were conducted". Strangely, abstract mentions polymer types ID'ed via FTIR, but body mentions no such thing.
assuming "water sampler" = scoop. Includes only river section (omits estuary samples)
wwtp effluent sites. 4L bottles used to scoop 100L total. Top 5cm sampled. I averaged upstream of wwtp average with downstream of wwtp average.
Pearl river. "5L water sampler" assumed to be a grab since aggrigating? ~2 fibers/blank, but all were cotton
5-10cm below water surface. Concentration taken from table 2.
includes river and reservoir samples
Estuary and bay.

took average of range of river discharges during sampling to calculate average volume per sample. Took average of rural & urban+rural catchment concentration averages (but table 2 is confusing so may not be reading sites correctly). "10 samplings".
caspian sea. They only looked at things larger than 0.3mm. Reported in items/km2. I divided by full diameter of net. GPS not specified, but I've assumed that is how they determined distance trawled.

estimate trawl volume estimates to have 1% error (always). I've used their extrapolated results from Results: Trawl: Precision. Our estimate based on net dimensions & trawl distance would be (.675*.2/2)*(1852*.5) which is 62,505L
included only pump with same size as trawl. There are two other pump filter sizes available.
harbor. Duplicate trawls. Assumed half of net height submerged
averaged high & low flow averages. Volumes averaged from supp. Materials

assumed manta half submerged. Converted from /km2 to /L. Sampling area (km2) was calculated for concentrations in the manuscript using GPS distance, eventhough they had a flowmeter attached to the net. poly(methyl methacrylate) = acrylic or PMMA

averaged estuary, harbor, open water and nearshore averages (items/km2) and divided by 1/2 of net opening. FTIR used on 19 of the 68 particles already analyzed by Pyr-GC/MS: most common polymer via FTIR = PE, then PET. NOTE: this may mean frequency of FTIR-ID'ed PE and PET, may be a simplification of copolymers. Also fibers are hard to ID with FTIR.
averaged all stations: volume and concentration available in supp materials. Unclear if blank total was 31 particles in 10 samples or a max of 31 particles. I've assumed the latter to be conservative
averaged all site hauling volumes from table 1. Determined from table 1 that conversion between m2 and m3 is /10 and used this to convert concentration in /m2 to /m3
volume & concentration from supp materials. [volume calculated with tow speed + net dimensions = 156,263L]
mentions river/estuary samples being collected in 50L grabs but not mentioned in results
sampling depth = .5m. ATR mode of micro FTIR used.
atr-ftir. 15L stainless steel buckets used to create 120L samples
centrifugal pump. Sampled at 0.5m depth. FTIR and microFTIR. Volume: "The flux was recorded by double water meters, also estimated according to the sampling time."
average concentration from figure S8 (eyeballed it)

Included average of two river samples and marine sites since all were highly tidal estuarine. Concentrations are from table 3 corrected numbers. Samples collected by pumping water into jars and subsequently sieving it.
took surface water values only. Averaged all month & location together. Samples in triplicate.
Report fibers only
visual, with FTIR on 11% subsample. Flood tide. Rinsed through metal mesh (I've called sieve) before filtration
all data available. Flood tide
triplicate samples. Tibet. Assumining flow sampler had built-in flowmeter, but this is not specified in text. Wpo.

selected (and included for this row) only natural river sites also sampled (ignoring fish ponds): two streams in lake balaton catchment, an inlet of lake Tisza-to and river Tisza. Estimated fourth concentration value based on figure 1. Used only FTIR microscope (with ftir off, which is in essence a compound microscope, in my understanding).

paired sample, net & pump. Very coastal. Pumped .2m below surface. Including estuary, concentration is given in supp materials table S3 as 174 items/m3; concentration listed in this row is estimated from figure 3, omitting 3 estuarine sites (checked estimate by including estuary sites and got within 0.003items/L)
0-20cm below surface
calculated average concentration with 2 values given in range and the rest from figure 2a.
Ruttner Hydro-bios sampler as listed is just a bulk sampler, but in the text it describes it as "pumping sampler", so is it a pump?
pulled in surface water values only (ignored shrimp). Samples were filtered through 20micron nylon membranes with the vacuum pump in lab. I've classified this as mesh.
ofanto river Italy. 3 nets side-by-side. All sample volumes available in supp material
four different rivers averaged (all drain into each other). 3-5 replicates per site. All volume & concentration values available in supp materials

atr-ftir. Lowest size categorized: 0.1mm. Sem used for surface. Sounds like all particles were id'ed under ftir first. Concentrations averaged across wet & dry seasons and all sites from supp materials.
averaged two sampling sites (gyres). Pumped directly through plankton net on board

paired sample, net & pump. Very coastal, should be estuary? Had to pull concentration values off of graph and not sure if they're trustworthy? Abundance items/m3 S10, S11, S12 (not included in this row): 4,2.25,2.5. Also volume m3 S10, S11, S12 (omitted): 107.7,120.5,160.5

paired sample, net & pump. Very coastal. Should be estuary? Had to pull concentration values off of graph and not sure if they're trustworthy? Omitted volumes m3 S10, S11, S12: 107.5,120.5,160.3. Omitted abundances items/m3 S10, S11, S12: 4.5,1.5,3.25
averaged concentrations from table 2
assumed manta half submerged. Included only canary & madeira data
averaged towing distance range given to calc volume. Assumed manta mouth 1/2 submerged

Net mesh = .1mm, but in lab, sieved to .355mm for some reason. calculated volume based on average speed and net depth given. Estimated concentration based on numbers given in range and guestimating from fig 4 graph. Excludes Las Vegas wash, which used different methods

all numbers given. Proprietary neuston net like sampler. Doesn't specifically list mesh size of sampler. No specific mention of GPS but I've assumed that's how they followed "1.8 km of imaginary transect lines"

atr-ftir. Concentration given. Data for download: https://doi.org/10.14466/CefasDataHub.68. Found distance traveled from this data's GPS start/end coords. multiplied it times an assumed 1/2 net mouth submerged to get volume in L.
averaged all estuary sites
volumes in supp materials. "blue and red colors were the most abundant"
avg. conc given. Trawl volumes averaged from table S1 (given in 10^3 m3)
assumed sampling depth of .3 to convert concentration from /m2 to /m3. Omitted sites S2, S5, S8, S10 from concentration and volume calculations (they are river samples). Concentrations from Table 1.
